definition:
Let $f(z)$ be given uniquely in a neighborhood of the point $z$ in
$\mathbb{C}$. If the difference quotient
$$\frac{\Delta f}{\Delta z} \;=\; \frac{f(z+\Delta z)-f(z)}{\Delta z}$$
tends to a finite limit $A$ as $\Delta z \to 0$, then $A$ is the
[*derivative*]{} of $f$ at the point $z$ and is denoted by
$$\begin{aligned}
f'(z) = A = \lim_{\Delta z \to 0}\frac{\Delta f}{\Delta z}.\end{aligned}$$
Thus the difference $\lambda = \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta z}-A$ tends to
zero simultaneously with $\Delta z$, and $\Delta f$ has the expansion
$$\Delta f = A\Delta z+\lambda\Delta z.$$ If we denote
$|\Delta z| \;=:\; \varrho$, we have
$$\lambda\Delta z = \frac{\lambda\Delta z}{\varrho}\cdot\varrho
\;=\; \langle\varrho\rangle\varrho$$ where $\langle\varrho\rangle$ means
a complex number vanishing when $|\Delta z| = \varrho \to 0$.
Consequently, (1) implies $$\begin{aligned}
\Delta f \;=\; A\Delta z+\langle\varrho\rangle\varrho\end{aligned}$$ in
which $A = f'(z)$ and $\varrho = |\Delta z|$. It’s easily seen that the
conditions (1) and (2) are equivalent. The latter expresses the
[*differentiability*]{} of $f$ at $z$. By it one can sayt that the
increment of $f$ is “locally proportional” to the increment of $z$. Cf.
the consideration of differential of real functions.\

[9]{} : [*Johdatus funktioteoriaan*]{} (‘Introduction to function
theory’). Mercatorin kirjapaino, Helsinki (1936).

: [*Funktioteoria*]{}. Kustannusosakeyhtiö Otava, Helsinki (1963).

\
phrase: Derivative And Differentiability Of Complex Function
